docs.title: Welcome to BEAR GUI
docs.text:
The graphical user interface for the BEAR Toolbox allows you to estimate and run a variety of vector autoregressive models (VARs) without needing to write your own code.

Your first select the input data, the type of model to estimate, and the tasks to execute. Then, the GUI will generate a Matlab script for you that can run, viewed, and further edited.

docs.title: Estimator
docs.text: $INDEX_CONTENT Click here

docs.title: List of names
docs.text:
Enter a list of names separated by one or more spaces (use more than one space for a visual aid); for example:

GDP CPI UNEMP

docs.title: Vector of numbers
docs.text:
Enter a vector of numbers separated by one or more spaces (use more than one space for a visual aid); for example:

1.5 2.3 3.7 4.0

docs.title: Single date (period)
docs.text:
Enter a single date (period) as a SDMX date string. The BEAR Toolbox supports periods of annual, quarterly, monthly and daily frequencies:

Frequency SDMX format Example Annual YYYY 2035 Quarterly YYYY-QX 2035-Q2 Monthly YYYY-MM 2035-07 Daily YYYY-MM-DD 2035-07-21

docs.title: Span (date range)
docs.text:
Enter the start date (period) and the end date (period) as two SDMX date strings spearated by a space. The BEAR Toolbox supports spans of annual, quarterly, monthly and daily frequencies:

Frequency SDMX format Example Annual YYYY YYYY 2030 2035 Quarterly YYYY-QX YYYY-QX 2030-Q2 2035-Q3 Monthly YYYY-MM YYYY-MM 2030-05 2035-07 Daily YYYY-MM-DD YYYY-MM-DD 2030-05-21 2035-07-15

docs.title: Your notes
docs.text: ?NOTES?

docs.title: Long-run constraints
docs.text:
Configure the settings for the long-run prior dummy observations, then enter the long-run constraints in the table.

Tip

Scroll down for instructions on how to input different types of values.

Warning

After making changes in the form below, remember to press the Submit button, otherwise your changes will be discarded when you navigate away from this page.

?FORM?

Edit the long-run constraints table

docs.title: Selection of dummy observations
docs.text:
Choose no, one, or multiple dummy observations. The dummy observations will be included in the estimation procedure as extra data points.

Warning

After making changes in the form below, remember to press the Submit button, otherwise your changes will be discarded when you navigate away from this page.

?FORM?

docs.title: Your notes
docs.text: ?NOTES?

docs.title: Selection of estimator
docs.text:
Choose a reduced-form estimation method for your model, then proceed to customize the estimator settings. Only when you choose an estimation method can you proceed to the next steps: filling in meta information, choosing identification scheme, and setting up executable tasks.

Currently selected estimator: ?CURRENT_SELECTION?

Warning

After making changes in the form below, remember to press the Submit button, otherwise your changes will be discarded when you navigate away from this page.

?FORM?

docs.title: Inequality (sign) restrictions
docs.text:
1. Open the inequality restrictions table, and enter your restrictions.

  2. Save and close the file. Saving and closing the file is critical to ensure that your input is applied.

  3. Choose the other settings.

Edit inequality (sign) restrictions table

?FORM?

docs.title: Instant zero restrictions
docs.text:
1. Open the instant zero restrictions table, and enter your restrictions.

  2. Save and close the file. Saving and closing the file is critical to ensure that your input is applied.

  3. Choose the other settings.

Edit the instant zero restrictions table

?FORM?

docs.title: Cholesky
docs.text:
Choose the settings for the Cholesky (triangular) identification scheme.

Tip

Scroll down for instructions on how to input different types of values.

Warning

After making changes in the form below, remember to press the Submit button, otherwise your changes will be discarded when you navigate away from this page.

?FORM?

docs.text:
1. Open the generalized restrictions file, and enter your restrictions.

  2. Save and close the file. Saving and closing the file is critical to ensure that your input is applied.

  3. Choose the other settings.

Edit generalized restrictions file

?FORM?

docs.title: Your notes
docs.text: ?NOTES?

docs.title: Selection of identification scheme
docs.text:
Choose a structural identification scheme for your model. If none is selected, some tasks that require identification will not be available (e.g. shock responses or conditional forecasts).

Currently selected identification scheme: ?CURRENT_SELECTION?

Warning

After making changes in the form below, remember to press the Submit button, otherwise your changes will be discarded when you navigate away from this page.

?FORM?

Matlab script name: ?SCRIPT_NAME?

Assemble a script to run the selected tasks

View and edit the script

Run the script

docs.title: Script code listing
docs.text:
Matlab script name: ?SCRIPT_NAME?

?LISTING?

docs.title: Your notes
docs.text: ?NOTES?

docs.title: Script settings
docs.text:
The tasks selected on the Tasks to execute tab will be translated into a Matlab script, and save in your current model directory. You can then execute, view and edit this script.

Tip

Scroll down for instructions on how to input different types of values.

Warning

After making changes in the form below, remember to press the Submit button, otherwise your changes will be discarded when you navigate away from this page.

?FORM?

docs.title: Conditional forecast
docs.text:
Configure the conditional forecast settings, and then complete the conditioning tables, i.e. conditionig data and conditioning plan.

Tip

Scroll down for instructions on how to input different types of values.

Warning

After making changes in the form below, remember to press the Submit button, otherwise your changes will be discarded when you navigate away from this page.

?FORM?

Edit conditioning data table

Edit conditioning plan table

docs.text:
Enter the start date (period) and the end date (period) as two SDMX date strings spearated by a space. The BEAR Toolbox supports spans of annual, quarterly, monthly and daily frequencies:

Frequency SDMX format Example Annual YYYY YYYY 2030 2035 Quarterly YYYY-QX YYYY-QX 2030-Q2 2035-Q3 Monthly YYYY-MM YYYY-MM 2030-05 2035-07 Daily YYYY-MM-DD YYYY-MM-DD 2030-05-21 2035-07-15

docs.title: Selection of tasks
docs.text:
Choose one or mutliple tasks to run. To run these tasks, the GUI will create one single executable Matlab script. You can view and edit this script and run it repeatedly.

Warning

After making changes in the form below, remember to press the Submit button, otherwise your changes will be discarded when you navigate away from this page.

?FORM?

docs.title: Unconditional forecast using structural model
docs.text:
Configure the unconditional forecast with a structural model.

Tip

Scroll down for instructions on how to input different types of values.

Warning

After making changes in the form below, remember to press the Submit button, otherwise your changes will be discarded when you navigate away from this page.

?FORM?

How to enter values of different typesDetails of the individual settings

docs.title: List of names
docs.text:
Enter a list of names separated by one or more spaces (use more than one space for a visual aid); for example:

GDP CPI UNEMP

docs.title: Vector of numbers
docs.text:
Enter a vector of numbers separated by one or more spaces (use more than one space for a visual aid); for example:

1.5 2.3 3.7 4.0

docs.title: Single date (period)
docs.text:
Enter a single date (period) as a SDMX date string. The BEAR Toolbox supports periods of annual, quarterly, monthly and daily frequencies:

Frequency SDMX format Example Annual YYYY 2035 Quarterly YYYY-QX 2035-Q2 Monthly YYYY-MM 2035-07 Daily YYYY-MM-DD 2035-07-21

docs.title: Span (date range)
docs.text:
Enter the start date (period) and the end date (period) as two SDMX date strings spearated by a space. The BEAR Toolbox supports spans of annual, quarterly, monthly and daily frequencies:

Frequency SDMX format Example Annual YYYY YYYY 2030 2035 Quarterly YYYY-QX YYYY-QX 2030-Q2 2035-Q3 Monthly YYYY-MM YYYY-MM 2030-05 2035-07 Daily YYYY-MM-DD YYYY-MM-DD 2030-05-21 2035-07-15
